body_html:
Yes; it's an extension now that bijector inverses (and inverse log det jacobian functions) can return tuples - under the assumption that the preimage is always len(tuple)-valued. I believe that the special case of t=0 should continue to work for HalfNormal due to the way TransformedDistribution treats these values, but if not then you may have to special case that value.
…

As an aside, the docs state that bijectors implement bijective differentiable transforms, but the absolute value function is not a bijection. Am I right in guessing bijectors is moving towards being a more general set of transforms for distributions? — You are receiving this because you were assigned.  As an aside, the docs state that bijectors implement bijective
 differentiable transforms, but the absolute value function is not a

body:
Yes; it's an extension now that bijector inverses (and inverse log det
jacobian functions) can return tuples - under the assumption that the
preimage is always len(tuple)-valued.  I believe that the special case of
t=0 should continue to work for HalfNormal due to the way
TransformedDistribution treats these values, but if not then you may have
to special case that value.

On Fri, Nov 10, 2017 at 2:55 PM, Charles Shenton <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Thank for bringing that to my attention. If that's available, I'll
> implement a the FoldedNormal with HalfNormal as a special case.
>
> As an aside, the docs state that bijectors implement bijective
> differentiable transforms, but the absolute value function is not a
> bijection. Am I right in guessing bijectors is moving towards being a more
> general set of transforms for distributions?
>
